Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a variable angle spectroscopic ellipsometer

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The variable angle spectroscopic ellipsometer (VASE) to be acquired will provide unparalleled thin film characterization capabilities for a host of research projects in the Rochester, NY region. Examples of research projects include the fundamental study of thermophysical properties of polymer thin films deposited by a unique chemical vapor deposition technique, in situ characterization of responsive coatings in biomedical devices, comprehensive characterization of two-dimensional materials for photonic devices, and the study of laser-induced damage in optical coating materials for high power laser applications. Twelve research groups from the University of Rochester, Rochester Institute of Technology, and the Laboratory for Laser Energetics have been identified as users of the VASE tool. To further promote effective utilization of the VASE tool and make it widely accessible resource, it will be installed in a general user facility on the University of Rochester campus. Another key function of the VASE tool is to support student education to prepare them for potential careers in optics, semiconductors and photonics.

The proposed spectroscopic ellipsometry will be utilized for thin film materials of varied optical properties. Mueller-matrix ellipsometry measures all 16 elements of the Mueller matrix, which is the most complete description of a medium's response to polarized light. This enables quantitative analysis of samples with complex structure, such as optically anisotropic and depolarizing samples, while retaining standard ellipsometry capabilities, which are sufficient for isotopic, non-depolarizing samples. The specific instrument to be acquired is the RC2 ellipsometer, with additional enhancements to maximize its versatility and to enable multidisciplinary research efforts. They include an auto-translating stage for mapping of patterned surfaces and/or to assess film uniformity, rotational stage to measure anisotropic samples at several angles relative to the incident polarization, liquid cell for dynamic measurements of hydrated (solvated) films, thermal stage to characterize film properties as a function of temperature, environmental cell to measure films in controlled vapor atmospheres, and an electrochemical cell for coupled in situ electrochemical device characterization. The large sample stage and flexible physical configuration of the RC2 ellipsometer will allow future development of custom in situ characterization capabilities, ensuring the broad utility of this instrument in research projects for many years to come.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CBET project #1827904 provided for the acquisition of an advanced variable angle spectroscopic ellipsometer capable of quantitative Mueller matrix analysis to support a diverse body of research at the University of Rochester (UR) and other research institutions in the Rochester, NY region. The acquired ellipsometer (Manufacturer/Model: J. A. Woollam/RC2) offers a near-universal solution for ellipsometry characterization, capable of full Mueller matrix characterization over a wavelength range of 210 - 1690 nm. This enables characterization of complex films, including those that are depolarizing and anisotropic. Several optional stage accessories were also procured to enhance the tool's versatility across several research disciplines. These accessories include an auto-translating/aligning mapping stage to characterize film uniformity over wafer substrates, liquid cell for dynamic measurements of hydrated (solvated) films, thermal stage to characterize film properties as a function of temperature, environmental cell to measure films in controlled vapor atmospheres, and an electrochemical cell to couple ellipsometry and electrochemical measurements.

The ellipsometer was installed in a shared instrumentation lab in the Department of Chemical Engineering at the University of Rochester and made available to the entire university community and neighboring institutions. Since it's commissioning, the ellipsometer has supported the research of 24 unique users, representing 11 research groups from the University of Rochester, Institute for Laboratory Laser Energetics, and Rochester Institute of Technology. Extensive training opportunities offered through the instrument manufacturer has also been offered to users, providing them the knowledge needed to physically operate the instrument and model complex ellipsometric data. Furthermore, ellipsometry capabilities have been highlighted in multiple courses at the University of Rochester, and the ellipsometer has been utilized in the course, "Optical Coating Design", to verify the optical parameters of coatings comprising an antireflective coating design developed in the course. These educational opportunities have impacted approximately 100 students at the graduate and undergraduate levels.

A few select examples of research that have been supported through the acquisition of the ellipsometer include the development of novel polymeric coatings for lithium ion batteries, the fabrication and characterization of polymeric oil-diffusion barrier layers, the characterization of birefringence and film thickness in macroscopically aligned mesomorphic ceramic film and other novel optical materials, and the optimization of physical vapor deposition and chemical vapor deposition processing parameters for the development of novel thin film materials, including polymers, polycrystalline ceramics, glasses, and semiconductors. Many additional research examples have not been listed. Given its durable operation, limited maintenance needs, and broad utility, it is expected that the ellipsometer will deliver years of continual, critical thin film characterization and provide further invaluable student training.
